message: i'm jacob!

and there really is something to be said for a condensed introduction of sorts
I'm partial to Pro Django and Pro Python :) #shameless
@Gulopine the pro-python chapter (2? 3?) in pro-django is basically my go to for anyone looking to make 'that next step.' we give you much <3 here at mahalo.
honestly, i've never owned a python book. I did go through dive into python when I first started, but I prefer docs.python.org
i figured :)
how about http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/51vMQXPjBoL._BO2,204,203,200_PIsitb-sticker-arrow-click,TopRight,35,-76_AA300_SH20_OU01_.jpg
but prodjango isn't 1000 pages, it can't be good! (yes that's sarcasm)
@jacob we do have both
ah, yeah the mro is wacky fun :)
@convy i enjoyed the first edition, but i haven't read the second one yet
@jacob you do know that i expanded that into a whole book, right? :)
btw, what font is used in your pdf version, I love apress's pdf's for some reason, nice big bold letters.
both helped out when we had to do some hardcore tinkering with the mro to make wacky stuff work.
@convy the headings are Helvetica Neue and the body text is Utopia
@gulopine^
but just that chapter goes a huge way. and then if they're interested, pro python is right there for them
and it really hammer homes the point that a lot of 'came to python from django' devs that most of the fancy stuff you want to do is a pythong problem, not django
could be, but i certainly didn't know that when i wrote mine :)

@jacob @Gulopine (ahh twitter) The book I cowrote (http://withdjango.com) also made the decision early on to have a solid python intro chapter. Feedback about that has been nothing but positive. I think it's a common thing for framework books, though.
I don't think we did a survey or anything -- but now that I know yours did, ours did, and both Rails books I've looked at have a Ruby intro...it feels like a no brainer I guess
yeah, it really does make sense
@Gulopine could I somehow replicate that pdf generation?  how hard is it to get that kind of quality?

As a beginner I read this book and loved the fact that you end up with an awesome delicious like site at the end. I hope it will get an update http://www.amazon.com/Django-Website-Development-Ayman-Hourieh/dp/1847196780/
sf
One of the best books on python - which is hard, when there is so much documentation online - but this book is great: http://www.dabeaz.com/per.html
My favorites are "Python in a Nutshell" and "Practical Django Projects".
Are there any Django 1.3 books in the works?
@webmaven I don't know of any, but honestly djangobook (.com) is a great resource and once you understand the concepts there, you won't have much trouble getting up to speed on django 1.3

I also really recommend Pro Django. There's nothing else out there like it for moving the next step. I still end up pulling it out a couple times a week to re-read sections. Also I recently got Doug Hellman's "The Python Standard Library by Example" and that has really helped, as the docs for parts of the standard library can be a little opaque at times.
Pro Django has helped me to go further with Django / Python on some advanced concepts.
